construction, holomorphic branches

Let Ω\OmegaΩ be an open convex region in the complex plane. Assume fff is a holomorphic function on Ω\OmegaΩ and the real part of its derivative is positive: Re⁡(f′(z))>0\Re\p{f'\p{z}} > 0Re(f′(z))>0 for all z∈Ωz \in \Omegaz∈Ω.

  1. Prove that fff is one-to-one.
  2. Show by example that the word "convex" cannot be replaced by "connected and simply connected".
Solution.

  1. Let z1,z2∈Ωz_1, z_2 \in \Omegaz1​,z2​∈Ω be distinct. Since Ω\OmegaΩ is convex, the line γ ⁣:[0,1]→Ω\func{\gamma}{\br{0,1}}{\Omega}γ:[0,1]→Ω, t↦tz1+(1−t)z2t \mapsto tz_1 + \p{1 - t}z_2t↦tz1​+(1−t)z2​, is contained entirely within Ω\OmegaΩ.

    Write f=u+ivf = u + ivf=u+iv, where u=Re⁡(f)u = \Re\p{f}u=Re(f) and v=Im⁡(f)v = \Im\p{f}v=Im(f). Since fff is holomorphic, it satisfies the Cauchy-Riemann equations; in particular,

    f′(z)=∂f∂x(x)=∂u∂x(z)+i∂v∂x(z).f'\p{z} = \pder{f}{x}\p{x} = \pder{u}{x}\p{z} + i\pder{v}{x}\p{z}.f′(z)=∂x∂f​(x)=∂x∂u​(z)+i∂x∂v​(z).

    Thus, by the fundamental theorem of calculus,

    f(z1)−f(z2)=∫γf′(z) dz=∫γ∂f∂x(z) dz=∫γ∂u∂x(z)+i∂v∂x(z) dz=∫γ∂u∂x(z) dz+i∫γ∂v∂x(z) dz  ⟹  Re⁡(f(z1)−f(z2))=∫γ∂u∂x(z) dz>0.\begin{aligned} f\p{z_1} - f\p{z_2} = \int_\gamma f'\p{z} \,\diff{z} &= \int_\gamma \pder{f}{x}\p{z} \,\diff{z} \\ &= \int_\gamma \pder{u}{x}\p{z} + i\pder{v}{x}\p{z} \,\diff{z} \\ &= \int_\gamma \pder{u}{x}\p{z} \,\diff{z} + i\int_\gamma \pder{v}{x}\p{z} \,\diff{z} \\ \implies \Re\p{f\p{z_1} - f\p{z_2}} &= \int_\gamma \pder{u}{x}\p{z} \,\diff{z} \\ &> 0. \end{aligned}f(z1​)−f(z2​)=∫γ​f′(z)dz⟹Re(f(z1​)−f(z2​))​=∫γ​∂x∂f​(z)dz=∫γ​∂x∂u​(z)+i∂x∂v​(z)dz=∫γ​∂x∂u​(z)dz+i∫γ​∂x∂v​(z)dz=∫γ​∂x∂u​(z)dz>0.​

    Indeed, z1≠z2z_1 \neq z_2z1​=z2​, so γ\gammaγ has positive length, and ∂u∂x>0\pder{u}{x} > 0∂x∂u​>0 and is continuous, so it is bounded below by some δ>0\delta > 0δ>0 on a small segment of γ\gammaγ with positive length. Hence, the real part of f(z1)−f(z2)f\p{z_1} - f\p{z_2}f(z1​)−f(z2​) never vanishes, so f(z1)≠f(z2)f\p{z_1} \neq f\p{z_2}f(z1​)=f(z2​), so fff is injective.

  2. Consider Ω=C∖(−∞,0]\Omega = \C \setminus \poc{-\infty, 0}Ω=C∖(−∞,0] and g(z)=z1/2g\p{z} = z^{1/2}g(z)=z1/2, which is holomorphic on Ω\OmegaΩ since it is simply connected and avoids 000. Here, we choose the branch chosen such that g(x)>0g\p{x} > 0g(x)>0 on (0,∞)\p{0, \infty}(0,∞). Set f(z)=[g(z)]3f\p{z} = \br{g\p{z}}^3f(z)=[g(z)]3 so that for z∈(0,∞)z \in \p{0, \infty}z∈(0,∞),

    f′(z)=32g(z).f'\p{z} = \frac{3}{2}g\p{z}.f′(z)=23​g(z).

    This branch of g(z)g\p{z}g(z) maps to the right-half plane, and so Re⁡(f′(z))>0\Re\p{f'\p{z}} > 0Re(f′(z))>0, but fff is not injective, e.g., f(1)=1f\p{1} = 1f(1)=1, and

    f(ei4π/3)=[g(ei4π/3)]3=1.f\p{e^{i4\pi/3}} = \br{g\p{e^{i4\pi/3}}}^3 = 1.f(ei4π/3)=[g(ei4π/3)]3=1.
